background.name: Northern Shiverpeaks
entries: The Northern Shiverpeaks are, despite the name, a central region within the Shiverpeak Mountains. Inhabited mainly by the Deldrimor and Stone Summit Dwarves, they are also occupied by Centaurs and Ettins. They are often used as the primary route to cross the Shiverpeaks, with the Frost Gate barring one of two passes. There are few to no primary Deldrimor settlements in the Northern Shiverpeaks, but the Stone Summit are known to have mines here.

background.name: Pre-Searing
entries: Once, Ascalon was a beautiful, fertile land of rolling green countryside and magnificent cities. Her people were viewed as a bit grim by their neighbors, but this was perhaps to be expected, given their never-ending war against the Charr. Indeed, it was their unfailing vigilance, their Great Northern Wall, and the blood they shed each year to defend it that had protected not only Ascalon, but also Kryta and Orr through the ages.

background.name: Protection Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many monk skills, especially Enchantments that prevent damage or provide healing, become more effective with higher Protection Prayers.

background.name: Ranger
entries: Rangers are unique in their ability to succeed with the help of, or even in spite of, their environment. Nature rituals allow them to manipulate the environment to hinder their enemies, or borrow the very power of creation to heal and aid their allies. They favor long-range combat, the bow being their weapon of choice, and can be especially effective from elevated locations such as bridges and cliffs. They are the only profession with the ability to charm animals, which then accompany them on their travels and assist them in battle, gaining experience and levels over time. Rangers are also blessed with survival skills that help keep them alive by causing regeneration of health.

background.name: Restoration Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Ritualist skills, especially those related to healing, life-stealing, and defense, become more effective with higher Restoration Magic.

background.name: Ring of Fire Islands
entries: Just south of the Tarnished Coast lie the volcanic islands that together make up the Ring of Fire. The large volcano at the center of the ring is where the gods reportedly dropped the Bloodstones before leaving Tyria for good. Of the islands that surround this one, many are still active. Ships that pass by the Ring report hearing the tell-tale hiss of scalding hot lava hitting the ocean, instantly vaporizing the saltwater into steam.

The reefs off the islands are formed of black pumice stone. There are very few natural ports, and those that might be suitable for docking would bring the crew of the ship within danger of being caught by a sudden, unexpected eruption.
There are no known settlements in the Ring of Fire.

background.name: Scythe Mastery
entries: Scythe Mastery increases the damage you do with scythes and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a scythe. Many skills, especially scythe attack skills, become more effective with higher Scythe Mastery.

background.name: Shadow Arts
entries: No inherent effect. Many Assassin skills, especially those related to defense and moving as a shadow, become more effective with higher Shadow Arts.

background.name: Shing Jea Island
entries: Shing Jea Island lies to the west of the Canthan mainland, southwest across the sea from Kaineng City. It is an idyllic place with farming and fishing settlements sparsely dotting the rural countryside. The primary population centers include Shing Jea Monastery and Seitung Harbor; the former being a center for profession training and latter the primary docks and center of trade for the island.

background.name: Smiting Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many Monk skills, especially those related to dealing holy damage, become more effective with higher Smiting Prayers. Holy damage is especially powerful against the undead.

background.name: Soul Reaping
entries: For each point of Soul Reaping, you gain 1 Energy whenever a non-Spirit creature near you dies. You may only gain Energy in this way 3 times every 15 seconds.

background.name: Southern Shiverpeaks
entries: The Southern Shiverpeaks is, as the name implies, southern portion of the Shiverpeak Mountains and home to the capital of the Dwarves. In contrast to the Northern Shiverpeaks, this segment of the mountain range is considerably harsher. All kinds of wildlife, such as Tundra Giants, Frost Wurms, Ice Imps, Blessed Griffons, and Mountain Trolls, roam the snowy tundra, and, in addition to Deldrimor and the Stone Summit, it is currently occupied by other warring factions: the Avicara Tengu, White Mantle, Shining Blade, and Mursaat. The northern and southern areas are connected by several long, winding, and treacherous valleys, heavily populated with dangerous indigenous creatures.

background.name: Spawning Power
entries: For each rank of Spawning Power you have, creatures you create (or animate) have 4% more Health, and weapon Spells you cast last 4% longer. Some Ritualist skills, especially those related to Spirit creatures, become more effective with higher Spawning Power.

background.name: Spear Mastery
entries: Spear Mastery increases the damage you do with spears and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a spear. Many skills, especially spear attack skills, become more effective with higher Spear Mastery.

background.name: Strength
entries: When you use attack skills, each point of Strength gives you 1% armor penetration. Many skills, especially those related to surviving and inflicting damage, become more effective with higher Strength.

background.name: Swordsmanship
entries: Swordsmanship increases the damage you do with Swords and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a sword. Many skills, especially sword attack skills become more effective with higher Swordsmanship.

background.name: Tactics
entries: No inherent effect. Many skills, especially defensive skills and skills that aid your allies, become more effective with higher Tactics.

background.name: Warrior
entries: Warriors rely on stout hearts, brute strength, and melee weapons to subdue their enemies and protect their allies. They generally disdain long-range warfare, preferring instead to charge directly into the fray swinging their weapon of choice. They can take a beating unlike anyone else. Warriors are equally comfortable wielding axe, hammer, or sword, though many choose to master one weapon over all others. Many Warrior skills require adrenaline, which builds up during combat to enable those skills, and usually results in major damage. Defensive tactics help the Warrior to avoid damage and protect allies, but Strength is the Warriors biggest asset, allowing this hero to do more damage with every attack.

background.name: Water Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Elementalist skills, especially spells that deal cold damage and slow or hinder your foes, become more effective with higher Water Magic.

background.name: Wilderness Survival
entries: No inherent effect. Many Ranger skills, especially Rituals, Preparations, and Traps, become more effective with higher Wilderness Survival.

background.name: Wind Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many Dervish Spells, especially those dealing with movement or cold damage, become more effective with higher Wind Prayers.

condition.name: Bleeding
entries: A bleeding creature takes slashing damage at the start of each of its turns.
The amount of slashing damage of the bleeding condition is determined by the effect that applied it.
The condition can be ended early by regainig hit points.

condition.name: Burning
entries: A burning creature takes fire damage at the start of each of its turns.
The amount of fire damage of the burning condition is determined by the effect that applied it.
The condition can be ended early by using an action to smother the flames.

condition.name: Cracked Armor
entries: A creature with cracked armor has their AC reduced by 3.

condition.name: Crippled
entries: A cripple creautre has their speed halved.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: A dazed creature can't cast spells as reactions, must cast spells which take a bonus action as an action, and any other spell takes twice as long to cast.

condition.name: Deep Wound
entries: A creautre with deep wound has their hit point maximum reduced by 20%.

condition.name: Disease
entries: A diseased creature takes necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns.
The amount of necrotic damage of the disease condition is determined by the effect that applied it.
Any creature of the same creature type as the diseased creature that is within 5-feet of it when it starts its turn must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or gain a copy of the condition.

condition.name: Overcast
entries: An overcast creature temporarily loses access to spell slots equal to the remaining rounds, going from highest spell slot to lowest spell slot, regardless of if they have already been used.
Further applications of overcast add to the existing duration.
Spells which have the Overcast property gain additional effects when cast while having at least one round of overcast.

condition.name: Corruption
entries: A corrupted creature takes poison damage at the start of each of its turns.
The amount of poison damage of the corruption condition is determined by the effect that applied it.

condition.name: Weakness
entries: A weakened creature deals only half damage with weapon attacks until the condition ends.

item.name: Potion of Arcane Recovery
entries: You regain {@damage 1d4} spell slots when you drink this potion.
The potion's blue liquid crackles with arcane energy.

item.name: Abaddon's Reach (Exalted)
entries: This longsword has a hilt which is in the shape of a mask with 6 eye slids, and tentacles coming out of it's back, making up the pommel.
'Act with magic, act within reason, act without mercy.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use Abaddon's Reach as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Abaddon's Reach is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
You gain a +1 bonus to your charisma ability score.
When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 psychic damage.
You gain an additonal 3rd level spell slot. You regain this spell slot when you finish a short or long rest.
{@bold Awakened.} When Abaddon's Reach reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
The extra psychic damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.
The level of you additonal spell slot inicreases to 5th level.
{@bold Exalted.} When Abaddon's Reach reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
The extra psychic dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.
The level of you additonal spell slot inicreases to 7th level.

item.name: Abaddon's Reach (Dormant)
entries: This longsword has a hilt which is in the shape of a mask with 6 eye slids, and tentacles coming out of it's back, making up the pommel.
'Act with magic, act within reason, act without mercy.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use Abaddon's Reach as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Abaddon's Reach is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
You gain a +1 bonus to your charisma ability score.
When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 psychic damage.
You gain an additonal 3rd level spell slot. You regain this spell slot when you finish a short or long rest.

item.name: Seeker (Exalted)
entries: This light crossbow is in the shape of a dragon's wing.
'Tyria's last hope rests on the unity of the races. The pooling of their strength. It is the only way.' is inscribed on the grip.
You can use Seeker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Seeker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d4 piercing damage.

The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if your target is within 5 feet of an ally. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
{@bold Awakened.} When Seeker reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
The extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d4.

The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if you attack with advantage. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
{@bold Exalted.} When Seeker reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
The extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d4.

The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, while you are concentrating on a spell. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Brotherhood of the Dragon

item.name: Seeker (Dormant)
entries: This light crossbow is in the shape of a dragon's wing.
'Tyria's last hope rests on the unity of the races. The pooling of their strength. It is the only way.' is inscribed on the grip.
You can use Seeker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Seeker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:

When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d4 piercing damage.

The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if your target is within 5 feet of an ally. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Brotherhood of the Dragon

item.name: The Core (Exalted)
entries: This flaming greatsword is made of ornamented deldrimor steel, with a heavy core of infernal iron.
'Offer protection to the weak. Give solace and shelter to those who need it. Be ye a salve to the wounded.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use The Core as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While The Core is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 fire damage.

On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you gain temporary hit points equal to the challenge rating of the creature (minimum 1).
{@bold Awakened.} When The Core reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.

On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you can cause flames to erupt, damaging creatures of you choice within 10 feet of you, equal to the challenge rating of the creature (minimum 1).
{@bold Exalted.} When The Core reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.
On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you can make one extra melee weapon attack as part of your attack action.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Core Warband

item.name: The Core (Dormant)
entries: This flaming greatsword is made of ornamented deldrimor steel, with a heavy core of infernal iron.
'Offer protection to the weak. Give solace and shelter to those who need it. Be ye a salve to the wounded.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use The Core as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While The Core is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 fire damage.

On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you gain temporary hit points equal to the challenge rating of the creature (minimum 1).
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Core Warband

item.name: Celestial Slicer (Exalted)
entries: This silver-bladed sickle glimmers softly with moonlight. When looking at the reflection on the blade you can see the night sky.
'Lead through actions, not words!' is inscribed on the silver blade.
You can use the Celestrial Slicer as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
You can use the Celestrial Slicer as a star map while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While the Celestrial Slicer is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
When attacking with the Celestrial Slicer you can use Wisdom instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
When you cast a spell that restores hit points, you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the amount of hit points restored.
{@bold Awakened.} When the Celestrial Slicer reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.
The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.

When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can target one additional creature and make a second attack roll against it. You can use this feature a number of times equal to you proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
{@bold Exalted.} When the Celestrial Slicer reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.
The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
You can maintain concentration on two spells. When making a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration, make one for each concentration.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Ascalon Vanguard

item.name: Celestial Slicer (Dormant)
entries: This silver-bladed sickle glimmers softly with moonlight. When looking at the reflection on the blade you can see the night sky.
'Lead through actions, not words!' is inscribed on the silver blade.
You can use the Celestrial Slicer as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
You can use the Celestrial Slicer as a star map while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While the Celestrial Slicer is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
When attacking with the Celestrial Slicer you can use Wisdom instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
When you cast a spell that restores hit points, you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the amount of hit points restored.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Ascalon Vanguard

item.name: Incursion Breaker (Exalted)
entries: This staff is imbued with powerful arcane magic.
'Our gift to the people of Tyria is that they never know just how much danger they've been in.' is inscribed along the shaft of the staff.
You can use Incursion Breaker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Incursion Breaker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
When attacking with the Incursion Breaker you can use Intelligence instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.

When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can give yourself advantage on that roll by taking force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus.

When you force a creature to make a saving throw to take half damage, you can take force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus, to give one or more targets of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell. If you give multiple targets disadvantage you take force damage for each target.
{@bold Awakened.} When Incursion Breaker reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.
The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
You can add your proficiency bonus to one damage roll of any spell or class feature, that requires a ranged spell attack roll or forces a creature to make a saving throw.
{@bold Exalted.} When Incursion Breaker reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.
The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.

You can deal maximum damage, instead of rolling for any spell or class feature, that requires a ranged spell attack roll or forces a creature to make a saving throw. You can use this feature a number of times equal to you proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Wizard's Court

item.name: Incursion Breaker (Dormant)
entries: This staff is imbued with powerful arcane magic.
'Our gift to the people of Tyria is that they never know just how much danger they've been in.' is inscribed along the shaft of the staff.
You can use Incursion Breaker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Incursion Breaker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
When attacking with the Incursion Breaker you can use Intelligence instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

When you force a creature to make a saving throw to take half damage, you can take force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus, to give one or more targets of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell. If you give multiple targets disadvantage you take force damage for each target.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Wizard's Court

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bone horror makes a number of Swipe attacks equal to half the level of the spell (rounded down) (minimum 1).

action.name: Swipe
entries: Natural Weapon: 3 + PB to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.
Bone Horrors are minions created by certain Necromancer skills (Animate Bone Horror, Malign Intervention, and Aura of the Lich) and the Minion Apocalypse Flux.

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

The Charr are aggressive, industrious, and wholly dedicated to becoming the preeminent species of Tyria. A savage race of sentient beasts, the Charr will use any means available to destroy their enemies: an ambush is as honorable as a fair fight, as victory is what matters. Though Charr have no concept of mercy, they can be protective of those within their tribe.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Grasp of Chaos has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the Grasp of Chaos's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally doesn't have the {@condition incapacitated} condition.

action.name: Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit; reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition prone} condition.
Grasps of Chaos guard General Kahyet in the Blacktide Den mission. They are allied at first, then become hostile after a short dialogue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Grasp of Chaos is a 2nd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Dexterity (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks). The Grasp of Chaos has the following warrior spells prepared:

trait.name: Evasive Teleportation
entries: Whenever it takes damage or is the target of a ranged attack, the Oni can teleport, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, to an unoccupied space it can see within 20 feet of itself (no action required). If this effect is triggered by a ranged attack, the Oni teleports just before the attack hits, causing the attack to miss it. This trait is suppressed while the Oni has the {@condition incapacitated} condition.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Oni makes two Claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit; reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

There are some who say that the demonic, savage Oni originate in the Mists, others from someplace even more distant, dark, and cut off from the world of sanity. They are killers from beyond, appearing from nowhere to butcher their victims, for what reason no one knows. Whatever their purpose or origin, the Oni are among the most deadly things on two legs in Cantha.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Oni is a 5nd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Oni has the following assassin spells prepared:

entries: Nature Rituals are a type of rituals unique to the ranger profession. These skills summon a spirit that provides a global effect to all those in its area of effect. Unlike Binding Rituals, Nature Rituals affect everyone in their range, enemies and allies alike.
The Nature Ritual spirits resemble miniature druids from the Maguuma Jungle and Melandru's Watcher, the avatar of Melandru, the patron goddess of rangers.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Charr Axe Fiend Boss can make two attacks it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

action.name: Axe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage.
Drub Gorefang is an axe-wielding Charr boss.
Puugh the Slasher is a Charr boss found in Ascalon. As with other Charr bosses, he is usually escorted by various different types of Charr.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Charr Axe Fiend Boss is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Charr Axe Fiend Boss has the following warrior spells prepared:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the Charr Axe Fiend Boss fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The Charr Axe Fiend Boss moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Charr Stalker Boss can make two attacks it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.
Slur Scarchest is a Ranger Charr boss located in The Great Northern Wall mission.
Klaww FeatherStorm is a Charr Ranger boss encountered in Fort Ranik.
Fling Bloodpelt is a Charr Stalker boss that is part of the guards for the Ascalon Prisoners after the Charr retreated due to the events of the Fort Ranik mission.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

entries: Whiptail Devourer

Whiptail Devourers are common foes infesting the shattered countryside of Ascalon. They attack primarily by shooting projectiles with their tails. Like all devourers, they are often hidden beneath the surface of the ground, bursting from their hiding place to ambush unsuspecting prey.

trait.name: Assassinate
entries: During its first turn, the whiptail devourer has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the whiptail devourer scores against a {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} creature is a critical hit.

trait.name: Chameleon Skin
entries: The whiptail devourer has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The whiptail devourer can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the whiptail devourer doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Whiptail Devourer can make two attacks it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Stinger Launch
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 90/150 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Whiptail Devourer is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Dexterity (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The Whiptail Devourer has the following ranger spells prepared:

entries: Carrion Devourer
Carrion Devourers are common hardy dangers found in the wild countryside of Ascalon, both before and after the Searing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Carrion Devourer can make two attacks it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) damage.

action.name: Fling Stinger
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Carrion Devourer is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Dexterity (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The Carrion Devourer has the following warrior spells prepared:

trait.name: Assassinate
entries: During its first turn, the carrion devourer has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the carrion devourer scores against a {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} creature is a critical hit.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The carrion devourer can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the carrion devourer doesn't disturb the material it moves through.
Plague Devourer

Plague Devourers are hardy natural dangers that infest the countryside of Ascalon, both before and after the Searing, although they have become much more common since the Searing. Like all devourers, they are often hidden beneath the surface of the ground, bursting from their hiding place to ambush unsuspecting prey.

headerEntries: The Plague Devourer is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The Plague Devourer has the following necromancer spells prepared:

trait.name: Earth Glide

action.name: Fling Stinger
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Hydra (Ascalon) makes as many bite attacks as it has heads.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Multiple Heads (Hydra)
entries: The hydra (ascalon) has three heads. While it has more than one head, the hydra (ascalon) has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.
Whenever the hydra (ascalon) takes 25 or more damage in a single turn, one of its heads dies. If all its heads die, the hydra (ascalon) dies.

At the end of its turn, it grows two heads for each of its heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken fire damage since its last turn. The hydra (ascalon) regains 10 hit points for each head regrown in this way.

trait.name: Reactive Heads (Hydra)
entries: For each head the hydra (ascalon) has beyond one, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only for opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Wakeful (Hydra)
entries: While the hydra (ascalon) sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

trait.name: Hold Breath (Hydra)
entries: The hydra (ascalon) can hold its breath for 1 hour.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Hydra (Ascalon) is a 10th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). The Hydra (Ascalon) has the following elementalist spells prepared:

entries: Hydras are large three-headed lizards that use potent Fire Magic. The Hydras in Ascalon are found in small groups of two to four, throughout the northwest territories of Post-Searing Ascalon. These groups tend to mingle with other indigenous enemies in these areas; for example, with Stone Furies and Boulder Elementals in the Ascalon Foothills, and Charr hunting bands in the Flame Temple Corridor. In the northern region of Dragon's Gullet, Hydra groups flock together in herds, forming lethal mobs when attacked.
Resurrect Gargoyle
Resurrect Gargoyles can be found in groups with Shatter Gargoyles and Flash Gargoyles.

trait.name: False Appearance (Gargoyle)
entries: While the resurrect gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a inanimate statue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Resurrect Gargoyle is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 9}, +1 to hit with spell attacks). The Resurrect Gargoyle has the following monk spells prepared:

action.name: Fling Lightning
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 1} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) lightning damage.

action.name: Resurrect
entries: Resurrect a party member from range, but at the cost of their actions next turn. Choose one friendly dead creature, which has not been dead for more than 1 minute, that you can see within range. That creature returns to life with 25% of their maximum hit points. The creature cannot take actions, bonus actions or reactions until the end of their next turn. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.
Shatter Gargoyle
Shatter Gargoyles are found in the company of Flash Gargoyles and sometimes Resurrect Gargoyles.

trait.name: False Appearance (Gargoyle)
entries: While the Shatter Gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a inanimate statue.

entries: The grawl (ascalon) has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Dark Devotion
entries: The grawl (ascalon) has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the grawl (ascalon) reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the grawl (ascalon) can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make another attack.

action.name: Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, or 10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 90/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

entries: Grawls are the grunts of the Grawl army. They are often found in patrols with a Grawl Ulodyte.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The Grawl Ulodyte has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

entries: The Grawl Ulodyte has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

entries: When the Grawl Ulodyte reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the Grawl Ulodyte can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make another attack.

headerEntries: The Grawl Ulodyte is a 2rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Grawl Ulodyte has the following monk spells prepared:

entries: Grawl Ulodytes are the powerful shamans of the Grawl. In combat, they provide a lot of healing support for Grawl warriors. It may be difficult to defeat groups of Grawl if they have multiple Ulodytes.

action.name: Radiant Scepter
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 90/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) radiant damage.
Boulder Elemental
Boulder Elementals are melee fighter elementals that rely on brute force to fight.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hurl Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Abaddon's Chosen
entries: Once per long rest, when the Margonite is below 50% of their hit point maximum, they can choose to become immune to all damage until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Margonite Executioner can make three hammer attacks, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Abaddon's Favor
entries: Once per long rest, the Margonite can choose one creature affected by Abaddon's Chosen, all creatures within 15 feet of that creature must succeed on a charisma saving throw or take {@damage 6d6} psychic damage. The target then regains hit points equal to the damage rolled.

action.name: Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, or 23 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

headerEntries: The Margonite Executioner is a 13th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). The Margonite Executioner has the following warrior spells prepared

entries: Margonite Executioners provide the melee muscle in a Margonite group. While their damage output is weak for a warrior, they can weaken and knock down party members.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

Justiciar Hablion was one of the few people who survived the Rise of the White Mantle, and thus one of the few people who could accurately describe the events of that night. He was one of Saul D'Alessio's closest allies up until his disappearance. He would later become a very high-ranking member of the White Mantle.

He first met the Ascalonian refugees at the Gates of Kryta, where they helped him clear the swamp of undead in exchange for asylum in Kryta. He would later encounter them again, giving them the Eye of Janthir to help them select the Chosen - they thought that they would be escorting them to the Temple of the Unseen, but in fact they were to be executed atop the Bloodstone. The Ascalonians learned of this and confronted Hablion, eventually slaying him atop the Bloodstone.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Justiciar Hablion is a 13th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). Justiciar Hablion has the following warrior spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Justiciar Hablion can make four sword attacks, he can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Load Shot
entries: At initiative 20 the trebuchet loads either a boulder, gravel or fire shot.

action.name: Fire loaded Shot
entries: At initiative 10 the trebuchet fires the shot it loaded.

action.name: Boulder Shot
entries: Choose a point that you can see within range. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 6d6} bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.

action.name: Gravel Shot
entries: Choose a point that you can see within range. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a DC20 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 4d6} bludgeoning damage and starts {@condition bleeding|GuildWars} for the duration, taking {@damage 2d4} damage. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.
At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.

action.name: Fire Shot
entries: Choose a point that you can see within range. Each creature in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage and starts {@condition burning|GuildWars} for the duration, taking {@damage 4d4} damage. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.
At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Dexterity saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.

action.name: Reset
entries: At initiative 0 the trebuchet resets.

trait.name: Damage Threshold
entries: The trebuchet only takes damage if it took at least 10.

trait.name: Requires operation
entries: At least two creatures must use their action to operate the trebuchet for it to be able to load, fire and reset.
A trebuchet, a siege weapon similar to a catapult or ballista, is a stationary map object used to inflict large amounts of damage to those in its target zone.

trait.name: Arcane Barrier
entries: While channeling an Obelisk, the Mage has an AC of 15, 100 hit points and a damage threshold of 10.

trait.name: Channeling
entries: While channeling an Obelisk, the Mage's STR, DEX and CON score get replaced by the Obelisks.

action.name: Obelisk Lightning
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) lightning damage.

reaction.name: Discharge Arcane Lightning
entries: When a hostile creature enters the Mage's reach or start's its turn in range, the mage can use its Obelisk Lightning attack as a reaction.

bonus.name: Obelisk Lightning

An Obelisk is a magical attack platform usually constructed with three upright pillars surrounding a central raised dais.

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

action.name: Flame Scepter
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d8 + 6}) fire damage.

Bonfaaz Burntfur is a powerful Charr chieftain and the leader of the Charr forces assaulting Ascalon. Players first encounter him in The Great Northern Wall mission as he prepares the Charr forces for an invasion of the areas of Ascalon south of the wall. Later on they encounter him in the Nolani Academy mission as he tried to capture the capital city of Rin.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

footerEntries: *Bonfaaz Burntfur casts these spells on itself before combat.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Bonfaaz Burntfur fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Cantrip
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur casts a cantrip.

legendary.name: Overcharge Effigy (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur chooses a titan effigy he can see and overcharges it, inspiring all charr within 15-feet of it. Each charr affected has advantage on their next attack roll, has their movement speed doubled for 1 round, and gains one additional action.

trait.name: Charge

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: They have advantage on saving throws against poison, and they have resistance to poison damage.

One of the oldest races on Tyria, the Dwarves are humanoids that are stocky, short, and are almost always bearded. The dwarves live in the Shiverpeak Mountains - specifically the Northern Shiverpeaks and the Southern Shiverpeaks.

In recent years, the dwarves have been plunged into a civil war between the older Deldrimor dwarves and the recent Stone Summit faction. This war has caused unrest throughout the Shiverpeaks and hold up most travel between Ascalon and the other human nations.

action.name: Warhammer

Deldrimor is a kingdom of dwarves residing in the Shiverpeak Mountains. They are very friendly towards other races, such as the humans, and passage through the harsh mountain range (which, along with the Sea of Sorrows divides the continent of Tyria in half) is welcome to anyone who is a friend of Deldrimor.

entries: The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss makes two attacks: two with its Battleaxe or two with its Shortbow, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d8 + 5}) slashing damage, or 27 ({@damage 4d10 + 5}) slashing damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss is a 10th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:
footerEntries: *The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss casts these spells on itself before combat.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss attacks using one of its attacks.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell
entries: The Stone Summit Axe Wielder Boss uses Spellcasting.

legendaryGroup.name: Bonfaaz Burntfur
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (winning initiative ties), Bonfaaz Burntfur can take a lair action to cause one of the following magical effects; Bonfaaz Burntfur can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

- Choose three points that he can see, designating them for destruction. An ominous sound can be heard when standing within 10-feet of a designated point. At initiative 0, a 3rd level {@spell Meteor|GuildWars} will impact at the chosen points.
- Bonfaaz Burntfur rallies the charr troops, increasing their morale and improving their abilities. All allied charr gain 10 temporary hit points.
regionalEffects: If the Stormcaller horn has been blown, all charr become vulnerable to all damage, and deal only half damage.

entries.name: Age
entries: Norn can have long lives, living up to 120 and maintaining their good health and vitality for a long time, though very few die of old age.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid. You are also considered a shapeshifter for any prerequisite or effect that requires you to be a shapeshifter.

entries.name: Size
entries: Norn are around 9 feet tall and have broad builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Menacing
entries: You gain proficiency in the Intimidation skill.

entries.name: Cold Climate Adaptation
entries: You have resistance to cold damage and can't be slowed down or hindered by snowy or icy terrain.

entries.name: Become your Totem
entries: Once per Long Rest you can choose to transform into your Totem animal as an action. When transforming choose an Animal with a CR of 1  4 your Level or lower from the list of available totem animals for your Sub-Race.
Wild Shape rules apply.

entries.name: Raven's Cunning
entries: When rolling initiative you can add your Intelligence ability modifier in addition to your Dexterity ability modifier to it.

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans are around 5 1/2 feet tall and have a wide variety of builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Favoured by the Gods
entries: When choosing this race choose a patron god. The patron god gives you a small amount of power in the form a cantrip, a spell and a resistance to a specific damage type. Your spellcasting ability for those spells is dependent on the god. You can cast the spell once per short rest.

Cantrip: {@spell Guidance|phb}

Damage Resistance: Radiant

entries.name: Trained Actor
entries: You can add a d4 to any Charisma (Performance) or Charisma (Deception) ability check.

You can also try to pretend to be dead if you make death saving throws. To do so you must win a contested Charisma (Performance) or Charisma (Deception) ability check against an enemy's Wisdom (Insight) ability check that tries to target you with an attack. If you succeed, that enemy thinks you are dead and does not target you with an attack. If they succeed they see though your deception and can attack normally.

entries.name: Age
entries: Charr reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Size
entries: Charr are around 7 feet tall and have a wide build. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Cat's Talent
entries: You have proficiency in the Perception and Stealth skills.

entries.name: Military Training
entries: You have proficiency with all simple and non-two-handed martial weapons.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of grey.

entries.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals 1d6 + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Infernal Magic
entries: You know the fire bolt cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the fire bolt storm spell as a 2nd-level spell with this trait; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. Once you reach 5th level, you can also cast the lava font spell as a 3rd-level spell with this trait; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. Once you reach 7th level, you can also cast the meteor spell as 4th-level spell with this trait; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma can be the spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with all simple weapons and the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Invoke the Great Dwarf
entries: As a reaction when you fail a saving throw you can send out a prayer to the great Dwarf. When you do so you succeed on that saving throw instead. Once you use this feature you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries: You have proficiency with all armors. If you already have proficiency with all armors, you gain proficiency with two skills of your choice.

raceFluff.name: Norn
entries: The Norn are a race of nine-foot-tall warriors who live in the northernmost Shiverpeaks. They revel in the harsh climes, leading dangerous lives among savage beasts. These mighty hunters are not organised into a single nation. Instead, those who display exceptional strength and prowess in battle establish homesteads, though they are certainly not considered 'rulers'. They often spend years at a time tracking a particularly strong or clever quarry; they never give up on a battle, a pursuit, or a friend.

The Norn revere the spirits of naturefrom the wolf to the snow lynx -- but the most powerful of these is the Bear Spirit, who, according to myth, blessed the Norn with the ability to change shape and 'become the bear'.

A race of shape-shifting half-giants from the north, the Norn value personal strength, victory, and purifying the soul through battle. They revere the spirits of animals and call on them like shamans.

The Norn are a highly independent race with a fighter-centric society, holding strength and prowess in combat above everything else. To a Norn, the greatest shame is not dying in battle, but rather not having the tale of their life, especially death, told. Due to their independence, the Norn are hardly seen in large parties with the exception of great hunts, festivities, and in the larger homesteads like Gunnar's Hold.

For the Norn, in order to wed, the couple must be of equal reputation, and marriage symbolises the combining of their tales. During the wedding, someone must speak on the behalf of the two to show their worth for the other.

Norn culture is highly individualistic with a focus on personal success and gloryparticularly when gained from the hunt or in a battle. The norn do not fear death as they believe the bold and strong can achieve immortality, but they do fear they will be weak and end up forgotten. As a result each norn seeks to prove themselves, to build their legend through feats of individual valour and great victories. Every norn hopes their legend will be told by the skaald and celebrated at a moot with story and song. Norn usually have a great sense of personal honour, for a norn without respect from others is already forgotten. For many norn, the focus on prestige means they're willing to accept any challenge which will prove their worth. They will never give up on their battle, quarry or friends, even if it means years spent tackling a strong enemy or difficult task. Yet for other norn the pursuit of prestige translates to bragging, bullying, unwise snap decisions and an unwillingness to listen to reason.

Norn are a hearty, proud peoplequick to anger, but also to forgive. They are, by their nature, a race of optimists, keeping a positive outlook even though they have been driven from their homelands. A setback is seen as just another challenge to overcome. They respect those who can best them in a fight so brawling among norn is common. Drinking alcohol, often to excess, is also a large part of norn culture. Being drunk and fighting is not an uncommon combination, for example, norn alemoots feature competitions of 'skill' which require the competitors to be very drunk to compete.

A norn might proudly trace their worthy ancestors through many generations and may pass a common name through a family (such as Olaf Olafson, seventh son of Olaf) but a great ancestry and family connections do not grant automatic respect to a norn. Everyone is judged not by their lineage or associated group but by what deeds they have done. There is no such thing as infamy to the norn; they are often tolerant of an individual to whom other races might treat with hostility by association.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Bear)
entries: As the Spirit of ferocity and confidence and the natural embodiment of all bears, Bear is the most revered of all the Spirits of the Wild and is said to be an icon of strength, insight, and wisdom. According to ancient myths, she bestowed the norn with the totem ability to Become the Bear. The norn view Bear as both a Mother who protects her cubs and a Sister who helps people find their inner strength. She is said to give norn the power to face all odds.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Wolf)
entries: As the Spirit of teamwork, friendship, family, and the natural embodiment of all wolves, Wolf is said to be dedicated to brotherhood as he imparts the virtues of loyalty, ferocity, and strength in numbers. He is revered as a masculine spirit, and the norn call him their brother, son, father, and uncle when they ask for his blessing. According to old tales, Owl taught Wolf how his hunting would be for naught if his family dined alone, making Wolf heed Owl's wisdom as he returned to his cubs. Although in some cases Raven was believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists, Wolf was also known to do the same to people who walked in his footsteps.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Owl)
entries: As the natural embodiment of all owls, Owl was revered as one of the Spirits of the Wild among the norn. Although she was a gentle Spirit who embodied home and hearth, she was also a silent and clever predator with ambush-like swiftness and precision. Helping the sick and wounded pleased her. Owl put her family's needs and safety above all else, often teaching others that the purpose of the hunt was not just to kill but also to provide and protect. Tales about Owl depict her offering her wisdom to both norn and her fellow Spirits of the Wild.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Raven)
entries: As the Spirit of knowledge and foresight and the natural embodiment of ravens, Raven is said to be a trickster who is fond of riddles and wordplay and likes to test the wits of his followers and anyone else who wishes to uncover his secrets. He calls his followers fledglings, inspires artists, and also favours acts of kindness towards ravens who are viewed as his flock. In some cases Raven is believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists.

The norn believe that Raven sees and knows all, and requires nothing but the petitioner's promise to always seek wisdom to grant them his blessing of swiftness. He only views someone unworthy in his eyes if the person does not learn from their mistakes, and he rewards the clever, the sincere, and those who seek out new experiences such as travelling the world. Although Raven represents the facets of mind that grant beings the vision to see and the wisdom to understand, his teachings also contain a darker side which some of his wayward shamans would cruelly embrace in their quest for knowledge and power at the expense of others.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human
entries: Humans are one of the most widespread and influential species in the world of Tyria. They are spread throughout the world of Tyria, including Cantha, Elona, and the eponymous continent Tyria, though it is implied they live further south than Cantha, which is where they may have originated.
Wherever they originated, humans are not native to the world as they were brought there by the Six Gods. The gods themselves only predate humans by a short period of time.
Humans arrived on the Tyrian continent in 205 BE. Since their arrival, three major human polities have arisen, Ascalon, Kryta, and Orr. Orr was the first region colonised.

Before the Exodus of the Gods, the gods lived in Arah (nicknamed the City of the Gods) and aided humans in numerous tasks such as pushing the Charr north so that the settlements that would become known as Ascalon could be established. With their aid, King Doric became the first ruler of all human realms. It was he who prayed to Dwayna to stop a war in 115 BE; it was he who pleaded to the gods a year before the exodus to stop the many conflicts caused by the gift of magic being given too freely; and it is his blood that seals the bloodstones.

After the creation of the bloodstones, the colonies of Ascalon and Kryta gradually split off into their own kingdoms - turning the unified human kingdom into three. During this time, open conflicts raged between the various human guilds and are now referred to as the Guild Wars. The Guild Wars were so widespread that they drew the Tyrian human kingdoms into war with each other in order to stop the battling in their own streets. It took the foreign threat of Charr to finally bring an end to the internecine conflict. The event now known as the Charr invasion ravaged the three human kingdoms, forcing them to put aside their squabbling or face destruction.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Ascalonian)
entries: Ascalon is a land filled with wheat fields, blossoming flowers, and natural irrigation throughout the fertile landscape. Ascalon is located between the Shiverpeak Mountains and the Blazeridge Mountains.

During the last Guild War, the people of Rin looked to Adelbern to lead them; he was crowned king due to his feats and popularity. Duke Barradin was the next heir to the throne before Adelbern was crowned and, as such, some of his supporters were not happy when a soldier was named instead. Some royalists, including nobles and members of the court, became bandits and took to the countryside.
Even though Ascalon is a beautiful place, it is riddled with threats from Skale, Grawl, bandits, and the Charr.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Krytan)
entries: Kryta was the third and last human kingdom to be established in Tyria. Originally a colony of Elona, it was established in 300 AE, it gained its independence in 358 AE. The kingdom's royal family are descendants of King Doric, however it is not known how far Doric's lineage goes into the Krytan royalty. There have been few notable members of this royalty, outside the last king, King Jadon, the only known monarch is Mad King Thorn. Those of the royal bloodline are buried in the Mausoleum, which is guarded by the undead dragon Rotscale.

Kryta is home to many important landmarks, such as the Wizard's Tower and the Temple of the Ages. It is also the origin of the now-mysterious Druids, former Krytans who left into the Maguuma Jungle to the west long ago.
Sometime in the distant past, several large watchtowers were built along the northern coast to defend Kryta against a threat to the north.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Orrian)
entries: Situated on a peninsula south of Ascalon and west of the Crystal Desert, Orr was a vibrant, proud, and prosperous nation. Its citizens were the favoured of the gods, living in the shadows of Arah, the deserted city once inhabited by the likes of Melandru, Dwayna, and Balthazar. Deeply spiritual, the Orrians looked after the buildings and structures left behind when the gods left Tyria, caring for them in the hopes that one day, the divine beings who created magic and bestowed it upon the world would return.

The Orrians were a peaceful people, hoping only to do their duty toward their gods and content to be rewarded in either this life or the next. When the guilds began feuding, Orr as a nation tried to stay out of the conflict. This was not the sort of struggle that entire kingdoms got involved in. But when the strife overflowed into armed conflict, and guilds from the other human nations began fighting in the streets of Arah, Orr rose to defend itself and the city of the gods.

Soon after Orr mobilised its armies, Kryta and Ascalon did as well, and what had started as a dispute between localised groups became an all-out war. The Guild Wars raged for nearly fifty years. During that time, none of the three human empires was able to assert dominance over either of the other two. While Ascalon, Orr, and Kryta were busy fighting with each other, they became blind to the threat from the norththe Charr.

The Kingdom of Orr was the first human kingdom established on the continent of Tyria, created by both god and man. From 100 BE, the kingdom was ruled alongside Ascalon by King Doric until his death in 1BE. Orr gained its independence in the year 2 AE. At the time of the Second Great Corsair War and King Zoran's reign, Orrian territory is known to have extended into the Tarnished Coast, and included the caverns now known as the Shards of Orr. Orr was once the most vibrant, proud, and prosperous human nation in the known world. Its citizens believed themselves to be the favoured of the Six Human Gods, living in the shadows of Arah which was once inhabited by the gods themselves. Orr was known as the nexus of arcane activity and research.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Vabbian)
entries: The northern province of Vabbi is known for its great wealth and refined culture. Merchant princes pride themselves on their large estates, prosperous businesses, and patronage of the arts. Its provincial government, the Grand Forum of Vabb, is a plutocracy: only the wealthiest princes in the land have the power to make laws. Their legislature is openly democratic, but secretly, a merchant with influence has more power than a counsellor with one vote.

Vabbian princes rule the land. Most plutocrats sponsor great festivals and celebrations to display their importance and influence. Celebrations in Vabbian estates are wonders to behold: Dancers flourish in their elegant fashions, gourmands sample cuisine, revellers consume epic quantities of alcohol, and cultured citizens enjoy great works of drama and poetry. Heroes are welcomed at these festivals, where their heroism is celebrated in songs and stories.

The Vabbi are effusive in displays of self-importance, but also keenly aware of how much they depend on other Elonians. The guards of Vabbian estates watch the mountain range to the north, while citizens on the province's southern border depend on neighbouring Kournans to keep them safe. Outside the walls of the grand estates, danger is everywhere. Raiders know secret passes through the mountains and mines, and monstrous creatures roam the landscape. Fortunately, every generation of Vabbi includes idealists who dream of adventurous journeys across Elona. New tales of adventure appear on the shelves of Vabbi's libraries each year, as actors portray new heroes on the stages of Vabbian theatres.

raceFluff.name: Charr
entries: The Charr are aggressive, industrious, and wholly dedicated to becoming the preeminent species of Tyria. A savage race of sentient beasts, the Charr will use any means available to destroy their enemies: an ambush is as honourable as a fair fight, as victory is what matters. Though Charr have no concept of mercy, they can be protective of those within their warband.

The Charr are a savage fighting race that once dominated the eastern side of the Shiverpeak Mountains. They fought anything they could - including themselves. Eventually the many warbands of the Charr united under a single leader: the Khan-Ur.

In the days before the Gods of Tyria brought the Humans to Tyria, the Charr battled with the Forgotten in the Blazeridge Mountains. Long after the Forgotten stopped threatening the Charr, the Humans appeared and, with the help of their Gods, pushed the Charr from their southern borders, conquering the land that became known as Ascalon in 100 BE. Along with being pushed back, the Khan-Ur was assassinated, preventing any hope the Charr had to retake their lands. The death of the Khan-Ur caused a schism among his four children, who became known as imperators, and brought the establishment of the High Legions - the Ash Legion, the Blood Legion, the Flame Legion, and the Iron Legion.

In order to combat the Humans, they sought gods to call their own, and at the volcano called Hrangmer, the Burnt Warband discovered gods for the Charr. Having found gods, the Shaman caste, the first Charr to unite under the new fiery gods, united the rest of the Charr warbands under their faith. Though one Charr, Bathea Havocbringer, rejected these new gods. She was quickly executed as a living sacrifice to the gods and the Shaman caste banned all female Charr from warbands and armies, sent to do utility work.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Blood Legion)
entries: The Blood Legion is one of the four High Legions in charr society. They are known for their prowess in traditional battlefield combat. The Blood Legion controls the largest known amount of territory of the charr, having both the Blood Legion Homelands as well as the lands on the eastern side of the Blazeridge Mountains.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Ash Legion)
entries: The Ash Legion is one of the four High Legions of the charr, famed for their spies, stalkers and assassins. They were formed by the Khan-Ur's spymaster, one of the Khan-Ur's children.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Iron Legion)
entries: The Iron Legion is one of the four High Legions of the Charr. The Iron Legion is known for its Siege Devourers, catapults, towers, and other mechanical works.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Flame Legion)
entries: The Flame Legion is one of the four High Legions of the Charr. The Flame Legion is renowned for its members' magical prowess and is most commonly associated with the Shaman caste.

To the Charr, flame is the physical representation of their gods. In order to keep the gods happy, they must first fulfil their obligation to the flame. To that end, the Charr have constructed a series of sacred buildings known as Flame Temples. On raised platforms, these bestial creatures have inscribed huge circular runes, which define and magically feed the sacred fires. Further defining the ring are pillars of pure obsidian or carved sandstone, sculpted to depict the faces of the mysterious creatures the Charr worship. Between these pillars, in the very centre of each of these temples, are the ever-burning Sacred Flames. The Charr believe that as long as the flames are burning, the gods are pleased. If the flames go out, then the Charr have failed in their duties and will be punished by the gods.

Each temple has its own fire, which is tended at all times by four Charr Flame Keepers. The Flame Keepers have only one jobto keep the Sacred Flame burning. This is the most prestigious position a Charr can occupy; only the strongest, most capable Charr can take this honour, and all other Charr bow to the Flame Keepers.

In addition to the temples, whenever a large Charr warband travels anywhere, they take with them a bronze brazier, lit at a Flame Temple by the Sacred Flame. These braziers are placed upon palanquins, which are then carried from location to location by four Charr Flame Carriers. Each night when they make camp, the Flame Carriers erect a flammable effigy in the shape of one of their gods, then ignite it and let it burn till daylight.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Dwarf
entries: One of the oldest races on Tyria, the Dwarves are humanoids that are stocky, short, and are almost always bearded. The dwarves live in the Shiverpeak Mountains - specifically the Northern Shiverpeaks and the Southern Shiverpeaks.

In recent years, the dwarves have been plunged into a civil war between the older Deldrimor dwarves and the recent Stone Summit faction. This war has caused unrest throughout the Shiverpeaks and held up most travel between Ascalon and the other human nations.

The exact origins of the dwarven race is unknown, but their legends claim that the Dwarves were forged by their god, the Great Dwarf, on Anvil Rock in the Northern Shiverpeaks. Over time the dwarves laid claim to the Shiverpeak Mountains, forming the Deldrimor nation. Though they traded with the human nations and were on generally good terms, the dwarves largely kept to themselves.

Sometime years prior to 1072 AE, Dagnar Stonepate, cousin to the ruling king, Jalis Ironhammer, created a splinter faction that opposed the Deldrimor. The Stone Summit was a group of xenophobic radicals who believed that it was the Dwarves' right to rule over all other races. Inevitably the friction between the two groups erupted into a civil war.
The Dwarves are a mining and smithing centric society with a monarchy.

Most of the Dwarves follow and worship the Great Dwarf as their creator and god. Outside of their creation legend, it is said that the Great Dwarf taught the Dwarves the fineness of crafting before he departed to the Great Forge, where all Dwarves go when they die. There are also dwarves who worship, or at least revere, Dwayna, Grenth, or the Great Destroyer. The dwarves who worship or revere Dwayna and Grenth only seem to appear during Wintersday. Many within the Stone Summit worship the Great Destroyer.
There is also a group of Dwarves within Deldrimor known as the Brotherhood of the Dragon who serve the oracle dragon Glint.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Dwarf (Deldrimor)
entries: Deldrimor is a kingdom of Dwarves residing in the Shiverpeak Mountains that are ruled by a king. They are very friendly towards other races and passage through the harsh mountain range is welcome to anyone who is a friend of Deldrimor or an enemy to the Stone Summit. They hold a capital in Thunderhead Keep.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Dwarf (Stone Summit)
entries: The Stone Summit is a xenophobic faction which has recently broken away from the Deldrimor dwarves while being led by Dagnar Stonepate. They have had some recent successes in seizing power and resources from the Deldrimor Dwarves, most notably in claiming the vast mine of Sorrow's Furnace, which became their main base
